Irish social, or '''[[Ceilidh|cÃ©ilÃ­]]''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ë|k|eÉª|l|i}}) dances vary widely throughout [[Ireland]] and the rest of the world. A cÃ©ilÃ­ dance may be performed with as few as two people and as many as sixteen. CÃ©ilÃ­ dances may also be danced with an unlimited number of couples in a long line or proceeding around in a circle (such as in "The Walls of Limerick", "The Waves of Tory", "The High Cauled Cap", or "Bonfire Dance"). CÃ©ilÃ­ dances are often fast and complex. In a social setting, a cÃ©ilÃ­ dance may be "called" -- that is, the upcoming steps are announced during the dance for the benefit of newcomers. The [[ceili dance]]s are typically danced to Irish instruments such as the Irish hand drum or harp.

The term ''[[ceili dance|cÃ©ilÃ­ dance]]'' was invented in the late 19th century by the [[Gaelic League]] CÃ©ilÃ­ as a noun differs from the adjective cÃ©ilÃ­.
